Eran como pequeños gabinetes angélicos, estaban atiborrados de querubines, santos y figuras como figuras divinas de todo tipo. Era como una cosa preciosísima que mezclaba la joyería con la pintura en miniatura y que las monjas se lo ponían sobre el pecho. Pero claro, el ánimo de los pintores y de las monjas por darle forma a escudos cada vez más complejos pues entorpecía su legibilidad, que eso es básicamente el barroco, es como queremos acumular y acumular pero todo se vuelve completamente ilegible. Claro, poco a poco dijeron pues le vamos a ir sumando unos centímetros al escudo, unos centímetros hasta que alcanzaron dimensiones que hacían, la verdad, pues un poco incómodos llevarlos sobre el cuerpo y que sobre todo los convirtieron como en una pieza de ornamento devocional y de orgullo criollo que era físicamente imposible apartar de la vista. O sea, si ves el retrato de sor Juana, lo primero que ves es el escudo. Entonces, claro, pues pasaron radical de las medidas de aquel pobre obispo y en 1673, o sea, muchos años después, el arzobispo Paio de Ribera, otro arzobispo, en una visita al convento de San Jerónimo en México, amenazó a las monjas jerónimas firmemente diciéndoles que tuvieran mucho cuidado, que tuvieran mucho cuidado con los escudos, que no excedan con preciosísimo curiosidad la sagrada pobreza que profesan. Pero las monjas pasadas pasaron radicalmente a.

The coats of arms were growing, diversifying and reaching other very ostentatious orders such as the Hieronymite orders. Then, towards the end of the 17th century, in the time of our Sor Juana, the coats of arms had reached totally and completely unmanageable dimensions and visually they had become super complex. They were like small angelic cabinets, they were crammed with cherubs, saints and figures like divine figures of all kinds. It was like a very precious thing that mixed jewelry with miniature painting and that the nuns wore on their chests. But of course, the spirit of the painters and the nuns to give shape to more and more complex coats of arms hindered its legibility, which is basically the baroque, it's like we want to accumulate and accumulate but everything becomes completely illegible. Of course, little by little they said that we are going to add a few centimeters to the shield, a few centimeters until they reached dimensions that made them, to tell the truth, a little uncomfortable to wear on the body and that above all turned them into a piece of devotional ornament and of Creole pride that was physically impossible to take out of sight. In other words, if you see the portrait of Sor Juana, the first thing you see is the shield. So, of course, they went beyond the measures of that poor bishop and in 1673, that is, many years later, Archbishop Paio de Ribera, another archbishop, in a visit to the convent of San Jeronimo in Mexico, threatened the Hieronymite nuns firmly telling them to be very careful, to be very careful with the shields, not to exceed with precious curiosity the sacred poverty they professed. But the nuns passed radically to.

Pero bueno, es uno de estos catálogos que nos gustan mucho a ti y a mí, porque tiene una prosa como densa y pomposa, insoportable. ¿Entonces, me dejas que yo te lea cómo describía uno de los autores del catálogo las fiestas de profesión de las monjas? Te lo pido, venga. Tres días antes de la profesión, una muchacha destinada a monja vivía los últimos momentos de su vanidad terrena, ostentando todas las telas y lujosos vestidos de telas exquisitas proporcionados por la familia. La muchacha era exhibida en ostentosos carruajes que la paseaban por toda la ciudad, visitando a parientes y amigos, asistiendo a pequeños banquetes que la despedían de la vida mundana, donde los parientes ricos le ponían medallas y monedas peluconas de oro que se guardaba en alguna parte de su corpiño. La monja Llegando el día de su profesión, el templo era ricamente adornado y profusamente iluminado por hachones y velas encendidas dispuestas en candiles repartidos por los retablos dorados de los interiores, alumbrando las imágenes que vería por el resto de su vida. En ese momento se abrían las puertas del templo y se dejaban de huir los cohetes en la calle que estaban con sus luces y anunciaban el inicio de la ceremonia, a la cual acudían los invitados, quienes ingresaban al templo ataviados con sus mejores casacas y anchos vestidos, partícipes de la boda aparentemente irreal de una mujer con el espíritu. A la ceremonia de profesión, la monja llevaría un Niño Dios que es padre, marido e hijo a la vez. Esto es un tema bastante incomprensible al que nunca vamos a entrar. El misterio de la Trinidad lo dejamos a un lado. Llevaba un Niño Dios que es padre, marido e hijo a la vez, una vela de cera que ofrenda en manos del sacerdote y orgullosa, ostenta su escudo en el pecho para anunciar sus devociones particulares, que a veces coinciden con el nuevo nombre que adopta una vez que quede dentro de la comunidad. Reina por un día, como en el carnaval, reina por un día. Llevará una corona con alma de metal y adornada de efímera cera, debajo de un velo que es negro en principio, pero que luego se adorna de perlas y piedras preciosas. El vestido formado por mantos, la plisa, las capas y las tiras que sostienen escapularios. En algunos casos se verán adornados con figuras de la Galatea y hasta pequeños barcos de velas pintadas realizados en cristal. Anillos, pulseras y flores. Amapolas, rosas, cempanzúchiles, mosquetas y otras flores silvestres completan el atuendo.
utterances.text_en: Because, of course, in preparation for this episode I got my hands on a beautiful catalog of crowned nuns, which in fact I uploaded some photos and they asked me if I could not find it? That is, I took it out of the library. But well, it is one of those catalogs that you and I like very much, because it has a dense and pompous prose, unbearable. So, will you let me read you how one of the authors of the catalog described the nuns' profession parties? I'm asking you, come on. Three days before the profession, a girl destined to become a nun lived the last moments of her earthly vanity, flaunting all the fabrics and luxurious dresses of exquisite fabrics provided by the family. The girl was exhibited in ostentatious carriages that drove her all over the city, visiting relatives and friends, attending small banquets that bid her farewell to worldly life, where rich relatives put medals and gold wig coins that she kept somewhere in her bodice. The nun Arriving on the day of her profession, the temple was richly decorated and profusely illuminated by candles and lighted candles arranged in candlesticks scattered throughout the golden altarpieces of the interiors, illuminating the images that she would see for the rest of her life. At that moment, the doors of the temple were opened and the rockets in the street that were with their lights and announced the beginning of the ceremony, which was attended by the guests, who entered the temple dressed in their best coats and wide dresses, participants of the apparently unreal wedding of a woman with the spirit. To the profession ceremony, the nun would bring a Child God who is father, husband and son at the same time. This is a rather incomprehensible subject that we will never go into. The mystery of the Trinity we leave aside. She would carry an Infant God who is father, husband and son at the same time, a wax candle that she offers in the hands of the priest and proudly displays her shield on her breast to announce her particular devotions, which sometimes coincide with the new name she adopts once she remains within the community. Queen for a day, as in carnival, she reigns for a day. She will wear a crown with a metal core and adorned with ephemeral wax, under a veil that is black at first, but then adorned with pearls and precious stones. The dress is made up of cloaks, the plisse, the capes and the strips that hold scapulars. In some cases they will be adorned with figures of the Galatea and even small ships of painted sails made of glass. Rings, bracelets and flowers. Poppies, roses, cempanzúchiles, mosqueta and other wild flowers complete the attire.
